head.title: A Catch to Inflation-Indexed Bond: Taxes

hedline.hl1: A Catch to Inflation-Indexed Bond: Taxes

block.p: A May 17 front-page article describes an inflation-indexed bond the Treasury Department proposes to issue. But you did not quantify an important economic element of any such bond: that a substantial part of what the Treasury pays would be taken back in income taxes.

A May 17 front-page article describes an inflation-indexed bond the Treasury Department proposes to issue. But you did not quantify an important economic element of any such bond: that a substantial part of what the Treasury pays would be taken back in income taxes.

Suppose that to save for college costs, a family in the 28 percent tax bracket invests in the $1,000 bond described in your chart (a 30-year bond paying an annual rate of 3 percent before adjusting for the 5 percent inflation rate implied in your example). The initial after-tax return is about $22 a year ($31 less the 28 percent tax).

Now consider the 10th year. The interest coupon is about $49. The tax bill is $36 -- 28 percent of $49 plus 28 percent of the accretion in principal amount during the year (about $80). The resulting after-tax amount of $13 equates to slightly less than $8 in first-year purchasing power.
If inflation or tax rates are higher, the loss of purchasing power in later years becomes even larger, and the after-tax, after-inflation cash return may even be negative.

The tax burden would be mitigated somewhat if the bond were held in a tax-deferred retirement account, although this arrangement would normally not be suitable for college savings. Alternatively, Congress could enact legislation to provide more favorable treatment than under existing law.
Apart from these possibilities, the overall after-tax after-inflation return for the family purchasing the bond in your example appears to be about 0.8 percent a year.
The Treasury's proposal is intriguing, but let us hope the public discussion will be mindful of its economic realities.
WILLIAM H. WEIGEL MARIO J. VERDOLINI New York, May 17, 1996
